bestBHT.bht: Simon, the father of Alexander and Rufus, was compelled to bear the cross of Jesus after Jesus became too weak to proceed. While Jesus carried one end of the cross, Simon bore the hinder part, providing some relief. This act of bearing the cross after Jesus reflects the call to discipleship, to willingly share in the suffering and sacrifice of Christ. It serves as a reminder that as followers of Jesus, we are called to take up our own crosses and faithfully follow Him.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He was 'the father of Alexander and Rufus'—probably better known afterwards than himself, as disciples."
Him they compel to bear His cross—sweet compulsion, if it issued in him or his sons voluntarily 'taking up their cross!'
It would appear that our Lord had first to bear His own cross, but being from exhaustion unable to proceed, it was laid on another to bear it 'after Him.'
Albert Barnes: After Jesus - Probably to bear one end of the cross.
Jesus was feeble and unable to bear it alone.
They compelled Simon to help him.
Marvin Vincent: Laid hold on [επιλαβομενοι] . Compare the peculiar word used by Matthew and Mark. See on Matthew 5:41.
- 32. Peculiar to Luke. See Introduction, on the gospel of womanhood.
Philip Schaff: To bear it after Jesus. The hinder part alone was laid upon Simon. The relief was comparatively slight; there is no proof that our Lord was sinking under the load.
He who bears the cross after Jesus, bears the lightest end of it.
Archibald T. Robertson: The soldiers had no scruples about taking hold of any one of themselves."
John Gill: They laid hold upon one Simon, a Cyrenian; father of Alexander and Rufus.
On him they laid the cross; that he might bear it after Jesus.
Jesus going before with the other end on his shoulder; which seems to be the order in which it was carried between them.

bhtAttempts.bht: Alexander and Rufus, the sons of Simon, are mentioned as being the fathers of these two disciples referred to in one of the commentaries. Simon was compelled to bear Jesus' cross, and it seems that Jesus, after initially carrying His own cross, was unable to proceed due to exhaustion, so it was then laid on Simon. The soldiers had no qualms about taking hold of anyone to bear the cross, and Simon was chosen for this task. It is said that he bore the hinder part of the cross, providing some relief to Jesus, who was feeble and unable to bear it alone.

Simon, the father of Alexander and Rufus, was compelled to bear Jesus' cross after Jesus Himself became too weak to continue. The soldiers laid hold of Simon to help carry the burden. While Jesus carried one end of the cross, Simon bore the hinder part, providing some relief. This act of bearing the cross after Jesus is significant, as it represents the willingness to share in the suffering and sacrifice of Christ. It is a reminder that discipleship involves taking up our own crosses and following Him.
